Cross tabulation displayed as percents or proportions

Source: R/perctable.R
perctable.Rd

perctable and proptable use the cross-classifying factors to build a contingency table of the percents or proportions at each combination of factor levels.

perctable(...)

proptable(...)

Arguments

…

arguments passed directly to table(); typically one or more objects which can be interpreted as factors (including character strings), or a list (or data frame) whose components can be so interpreted.

Value

a contingency table, an object of class "table", an array of percentage or proportion values. Note that unlike S the result is always an array, a 1D array if one factor is given.

Details

See table().

Examples

# perctable() is now defunct.  Use `tally()` instead
example(tally)
#> 
#> tally> # tally() is short-hand for summarise()
#> tally> mtcars %>% tally()
#>    n
#> 1 32
#> 
#> tally> # count() is a short-hand for group_by() + tally()
#> tally> mtcars %>% count(cyl)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 2
#>     cyl     n
#>   <dbl> <int>
#> 1     4    11
#> 2     6     7
#> 3     8    14
#> 
#> tally> # add_tally() is short-hand for mutate()
#> tally> mtcars %>% add_tally()
#> # A tibble: 32 x 12
#>      mpg   cyl  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am  gear  carb     n
#>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int>
#>  1  21       6  160    110  3.9   2.62  16.5     0     1     4     4    32
#>  2  21       6  160    110  3.9   2.88  17.0     0     1     4     4    32
#>  3  22.8     4  108     93  3.85  2.32  18.6     1     1     4     1    32
#>  4  21.4     6  258    110  3.08  3.22  19.4     1     0     3     1    32
#>  5  18.7     8  360    175  3.15  3.44  17.0     0     0     3     2    32
#>  6  18.1     6  225    105  2.76  3.46  20.2     1     0     3     1    32
#>  7  14.3     8  360    245  3.21  3.57  15.8     0     0     3     4    32
#>  8  24.4     4  147.    62  3.69  3.19  20       1     0     4     2    32
#>  9  22.8     4  141.    95  3.92  3.15  22.9     1     0     4     2    32
#> 10  19.2     6  168.   123  3.92  3.44  18.3     1     0     4     4    32
#> # ... with 22 more rows
#> 
#> tally> # add_count() is a short-hand for group_by() + add_tally()
#> tally> mtcars %>% add_count(cyl)
#> # A tibble: 32 x 12
#>      mpg   cyl  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am  gear  carb     n
#>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int>
#>  1  21       6  160    110  3.9   2.62  16.5     0     1     4     4     7
#>  2  21       6  160    110  3.9   2.88  17.0     0     1     4     4     7
#>  3  22.8     4  108     93  3.85  2.32  18.6     1     1     4     1    11
#>  4  21.4     6  258    110  3.08  3.22  19.4     1     0     3     1     7
#>  5  18.7     8  360    175  3.15  3.44  17.0     0     0     3     2    14
#>  6  18.1     6  225    105  2.76  3.46  20.2     1     0     3     1     7
#>  7  14.3     8  360    245  3.21  3.57  15.8     0     0     3     4    14
#>  8  24.4     4  147.    62  3.69  3.19  20       1     0     4     2    11
#>  9  22.8     4  141.    95  3.92  3.15  22.9     1     0     4     2    11
#> 10  19.2     6  168.   123  3.92  3.44  18.3     1     0     4     4     7
#> # ... with 22 more rows
#> 
#> tally> # count and tally are designed so that you can call
#> tally> # them repeatedly, each time rolling up a level of detail
#> tally> species <- starwars %>% count(species, homeworld, sort = TRUE)
#> 
#> tally> species
#> # A tibble: 58 x 3
#>    species  homeworld     n
#>    <chr>    <chr>     <int>
#>  1 Human    Tatooine      8
#>  2 Human    Naboo         5
#>  3 Human    <NA>          5
#>  4 Gungan   Naboo         3
#>  5 Human    Alderaan      3
#>  6 Droid    Tatooine      2
#>  7 Droid    <NA>          2
#>  8 Human    Corellia      2
#>  9 Human    Coruscant     2
#> 10 Kaminoan Kamino        2
#> # ... with 48 more rows
#> 
#> tally> species %>% count(species, sort = TRUE)
#> # A tibble: 38 x 2
#>    species     nn
#>    <chr>    <int>
#>  1 Human       16
#>  2 Droid        3
#>  3 <NA>         3
#>  4 Zabrak       2
#>  5 Aleena       1
#>  6 Besalisk     1
#>  7 Cerean       1
#>  8 Chagrian     1
#>  9 Clawdite     1
#> 10 Dug          1
#> # ... with 28 more rows
#> 
#> tally> # add_count() is useful for groupwise filtering
#> tally> # e.g.: show only species that have a single member
#> tally> starwars %>%
#> tally+   add_count(species) %>%
#> tally+   filter(n == 1)
#> # A tibble: 29 x 14
#>    name       height  mass hair_color skin_color   eye_color birth_year gender 
#>    <chr>       <int> <dbl> <chr>      <chr>        <chr>          <dbl> <chr>  
#>  1 Greedo        173    74 <NA>       green        black             44 male   
#>  2 Jabba Des…    175  1358 <NA>       green-tan, … orange           600 hermap…
#>  3 Yoda           66    17 white      green        brown            896 male   
#>  4 Bossk         190   113 none       green        red               53 male   
#>  5 Ackbar        180    83 none       brown mottle orange            41 male   
#>  6 Wicket Sy…     88    20 brown      brown        brown              8 male   
#>  7 Nien Nunb     160    68 none       grey         black             NA male   
#>  8 Nute Gunr…    191    90 none       mottled gre… red               NA male   
#>  9 Watto         137    NA black      blue, grey   yellow            NA male   
#> 10 Sebulba       112    40 none       grey, red    orange            NA male   
#> # ... with 19 more rows, and 6 more variables: homeworld <chr>, species <chr>,
#> #   films <list>, vehicles <list>, starships <list>, n <int>
